You can avoid the iteration by using the array [`join()`][1] method like: $(".appendHere").append(new Array(++n).join('
New!
')); Where n is the number of elements you want to create. --- var n = $(".CountThese").length; $(".appendHere").append(new Array(++n).join('
New!
')); .CountThese { display: inline-block; width: 46px; height: 50px; background: royalblue; } .appendedDivs { display: inline-block; height: 30px; line-height: 30px; padding: 5px; margin-right:5px; color: gold; font-weight: bold; background: dodgerblue; }
[1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/join

You can avoid the manual iteration by using the array [`join()`][1] method like: $(".appendHere").append(new Array(++n).join('
New!
')); Where n is the number of elements you want to create. --- var n = $(".CountThese").length; $(".appendHere").append(new Array(++n).join('
New!
')); .CountThese { display: inline-block; width: 46px; height: 50px; background: royalblue; } .appendedDivs { display: inline-block; height: 30px; line-height: 30px; padding: 5px; margin-right:5px; color: gold; font-weight: bold; background: dodgerblue; }
[1]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/join
